participants.participant: Philippe Bordenave, Senior Executive Vice-President, Head of Group Finance and Development

plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the presentation of BNP Paribas 2009 First Quarter Results. For your information, this conference is being recorded. Slides of the presentation are available on BNP Paribas Investor Relations website, www.invest.bnpparibas.com. .
I would now like to hand the call over to Philippe Bordenave, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

Thank you, Kath . Good afternoon. Welcome to you all. I would like to start with a few introductory words before taking your questions. In the first quarter 2009, BNP Paribas posted 1.5 billion net income in a still very challenging environment. This good performance was achieved thanks to positive contribution from each of our three activities; Retail Banking, Corporate Investment Banking and Investment Solutions, which is the new name of the asset gathering division. And this good performance was achieved despite a rise in the cost of risk due to the further deterioration of the economic environment.

The Group's revenues totaled €9.4 billion, up 28% compared to the first quarter of 2008. This performance is due to the business' good sales and marketing drive, as well as the Group's greater attractiveness and market share gains in the current banking landscape, as illustrated by several things.

First, the very strong net asset inflow of €13.4 billion in asset gathering activities, Investment Solutions, which came on top of €10.4 billion last year. Second, the net increase in accounts in our domestic markets, both in France, plus 65,000, and in Italy, plus 17,000. And three, the number one position reached by fixed income in the all bonds in euros league table for the first quarter.

The Group's operating expenses were up 16% compared to first quarter of 2008, but at constant scope and exchange rates, and excluding variable compensation, they were down 2.4%, thanks to the cost cutting measures implemented across all the businesses in accordance with the target to stabilize cost in 2009. And the operating division's cost/income ratio improved a lot, by almost eight points at 66.1%. And the gross operating income, which was €4.1 billion, was up 1.3 billion, plus 48%, compared to the first quarter of 2008, reflecting the Group's good operating performance this quarter and allowing it to absorb the additional cost of risk and value.

The cost of risk totaled €1.8 billion, or 128 basis points of the Basel I risk-weighted assets, compared to €500 million in the first quarter of 2008 and €2.5 billion in the linked quarter, the fourth quarter 2008.

In the Group's two domestic markets, France and Italy, the cost of risk remained moderate at respectively 35 basis points and 74 basis points. However, the downturn in the economy affected the other loan portfolios, in particular at BancWest again, Personal Finance, in Ukraine again, and also – and this is new – in CIB's financing businesses.

Beyond the cost discipline I have just mentioned, this quarter also demonstrated BNP Paribas' ability to adapt swiftly to the fast changing and challenging environment. In the first quarter alone, in fact, we met our full year stated objective to reduce market risk, as well as total risk-weighted assets. In an environment that has remained extremely volatile, the target to reduce market risk, in particular exposure to volatility, to dividends and to basis risk, were achieved, as evidenced by the decline in the value at risk by 46% compared to its level as at the 31st of December, 2008. This reduced exposures combined with the greater selectiveness of the financing businesses at origination led to a €20 billion drop in CIB's risk-weighted assets compared to the level at the end of 2008.

All in all, so while having continued to grow lending in our two domestic markets, the Group already achieved its target of an overall 20 billion reduction for 2009 at Group level. As at the end of March, so the Tier 1 ratio was 8.8%, up 100 basis points compared to its level as at year-end. This rise was due to the combination of several factors.

First, the Group's very strong profit generating capacity in the first quarter, which is adding 20 basis points. Second, the drop in risk-weighted assets, which is adding also 20 basis points net of the latent losses in the equity available for sale portfolios. Three, the lowering of the flow on the risk-weighted assets under Basel I, which is bringing 10 basis points, as we had said already. And so all that is 50 basis points, I would say, coming from our side. And the fourth factor is the participation in the second stage of the French economic stimulus plan, which brought also 50 basis points.

So now with this 8.8% Tier 1 solvency ratio provides BNP Paribas with a significant safety margin in relation to the Group's medium-term objective of maintaining the Tier 1 ratio always above 7.5%. These achievements were made possible, I think, thanks to the bank's diversified and integrated business model, well adapted to the current challenges. And BNP Paribas now has the opportunity to roll out this model to two new domestic markets, Belgium and Luxembourg, with the acquisition of Fortis that we hope to close shortly. This acquisition is well in line with the Group's acquisition discipline. It's a fantastic opportunity to build a Pan-European leader, rooted in four domestic markets in the Eurozone, geographically and culturally consistent with each other. We are eager to start moving soon.
Thank you for your attention. I will now be happy to take your questions.
Thank you. . Our first question today will come from Kian Abouhossein from JP Morgan. Please go ahead.
Hello?
Yes. Kian.
Yes.
The floor is yours.

Yes, thank you. I have a question first of all on fixed income. Can you please tell me how fixed income developed, when I look at the slow revenues? And how much of fixed income has come back from hedging gains/potential prop gain from the fourth quarter, so I get a bit of a better understanding? Could you also talk a little bit how the trend has been on a month-by-month basis in the first quarter in fixed income? And the second question is on equity derivatives. You discussed some of the further cleanups that you have done a markdown. Can you discuss a little bit how the underlying revenues in equity derivatives have performed both in the slow revenue side and the structuring side? Thank you.

Yes. On the fixed income size, I mean, there is no – I would say, you've seen that the parameters which are key for fixed income, especially the basis, for example, has remained as bad as at the end of 2008. There hasn't been any significant improvements. And so there is no mark-to-market, I would say, recouping of former losses in these results. The only thing we can say is that all those parameters have not deteriorated further, with the exception of the monolines price, which have widened quite a lot and which have also added another burden as we have reported in the figures we have given. So those good results were obtained in spite of additional cost of the monoline spreads and without any help from – any significant help from, I would say, improvements in the market parameters.

Now the main one – the main explanation of those very good results, which is the exceptional level of activity in the first quarter, especially on the primary market with issues from corporate, from banks and states, which were at record levels, I think on – at the level of the whole market, I mean. It was driven – I think it was driven by fears of renewed credit difficulties, which led many to anticipate their 2009 funding programs, probably. Also probably some lag effect of issues which couldn't take place in the fourth quarter of 2008. So we had an exceptional concentration of activity on primary market.

Then there were also huge volumes transacted on all segments of fixed income activity partly linked to the primary market business, by the way. And marginally driven by very strong client demand for hedging products. So we – well, in all kind of products, interest rate, ForEx, emerging currencies, very good activities in commodities as well, commodity derivative as well. So this is, I would say, the first thing which is the huge volumes in the market. The second thing was that we – clearly we are gaining market share in that market, in that big market we are gaining market share. It's visible in the league tables, because the league tables are officially recorded. But we feel that in OTC markets, in derivatives OTC market, even if there is no official record, we feel that we are gaining market share, partly due to a kind of fly to quality and there is concern on the part of our client. So a certain number of institutional clients are moving to us, and it's very beneficial to our franchise in terms of market share.

And on top of that I would say, for the few players remaining in that market and acting in that market, there is a widening of a bit of a spread, which is helped by the reduced number of market counterparties, also the reduced number of arbitrage hedge funds. So there is less competition from that side. And also bid/offer spreads are also widened by the capital constraints and probably – and some volatility also as well. So all of that is creating a very favorable trading environment. Plus I would add that the three yield curve movements were relatively favorable to the trading and to the management of inventories in that quarter as the short-term yield curve went down, which is, of course, helping the – reducing the financing costs of the inventories. So this is what happened, I think, in the fixed income.

Now I am not going to give you a month-by-month figure. I mean, we are still waiting for the quarterly results of the U.K. bank, so I'm not going to move to monthly reporting. Now the only thing I can say because it's very well known, and I think it has been the case for all big players in fixed income, is that the January month has been extraordinarily high, so higher than it was. But overall it has been a good quarter throughout.

Okay. But how should I look at it when I see that you are making in one quarter what you made in '06 in fixed income revenues? Do you think there is a structural change? Or do you think this is an extraordinary time, which you will adjust back to what we've seen in the past over the quarter?

I think they're part of both. I mean I think that there are structural changes, as I am mentioning, the widening of the bid/offer spread, the reduced number of market counterparties, the reduced number of big players in that market, less arbitrage hedge fund. All I said, I mean, capital constraints and so on, all that is structural and will remain therefore for long probably. On the other hand, the volumes, the high volumes we've seen in the first quarter are probably not going to be repeated each quarter, and so you probably have a little bit of both, the combination of both.

Now equity, in equity we are – well, the markets remain very difficult. The volumes, the client demands are down. The – more generally, I would say, the equity products are not in demand that much, especially in the first quarter, we are not in demand. I think that it is changing somewhat these days, but the first quarter was not very good. And well, especially the structured products are concerned, the clients demand was especially low. The other thing is that as we had said while reading our yearly results, we were in the process of de-risking further. We wanted to run the business with a lower level of risk and a set number of risk, which used to be quite manageable, where now – and are now very difficult to manage. So we have reduced that level of risk and it's very visible in the value at risk. And, of course, on the fixed income side it's easier to do that in good volumes and in a market which is extremely lively. While on the equity side, it was more difficult and more costly to do that in a market which was sluggish and not very active. So this is why the equity derivatives results are not brilliant this first quarter. But still we are pleased to see that they have at least broken even in terms of revenues for the quarter, and I think we're progressively improving and we're going to keep improving in the rest of the year.
And are you done with the de-risking of the equity derivatives business?

Yes, we are done, yes. All the de-risking is done. As we have said, now that we have the -- the value at risk has been half at the moment where the parameters remain very bad. You can look at it on slide 60, where you see that the average value at risk in equities went down from 66 million in the fourth quarter on average to 34 on average, and even 31 at the end of the first quarter. And so at that level we are below the level which was the level of the first quarter of 2008, for example. So we are – in spite of parameters which are much more – much higher and weighing a lot on the calculations. So the de-risking is done, and now both on the fixed income side and equity side, we are ready, I would say, to work normally in the market according to their new pattern.
And you can't quantify the cost of the de-risking?

It's very difficult because it's done in – it's completely interlinked with the normal business. So it's very complicated to do it. It cost something, but it's not – you can't draw any conclusion from that anyway. So – and it would be very difficult to try to track that.
Thank you very much and congratulation for the results.
Thank you.
Thank you. Our next question today will come from Jon Peace at Nomura. Please go ahead.

Yeah, hi. Good afternoon. A couple of questions, please. Firstly, you've been very helpful in the past in giving us some guidance and your expectations for the cost of risk. I just wonder if you could update us, have your views changed for the last quarter. And I guess specifically with regard to where you're seeing a little bit of upward pressure, for example, in financing.

And the second question was just on the balance sheet. Obviously, well done for getting your risk-weighted asset target earlier. I just wonder if you look forward through the rest of the year, what further progress you think you can get in getting risk-weighted assets lower? And with your Tier 1 targets – and I know this is looking forward a long way now – but when you think about when you might retire the preference shares, is there a core Tier 1 target you are aiming for, as well as the kind of total Tier 1 target? Thanks very much.

Well, it's difficult to answer – to make any outlook on the cost of risk, especially these days, as we are in the midst of recession, economic crisis which . And that we have tried to give some indications, to allow everybody at least to make is online on slide nine and 10 where we are giving the cost of risk as a percentage of Basel I risk-weighted assets, which is we are giving for loan now. And it's true that in each and every case it's not. So in domestic markets, I mean, it's slightly up or it's up in a proportion which is not really translating into big losses. But, yes, it keeps deteriorating in Personal Finance and we try to do our best. We are extremely proactive in managing the workout. We have – in each country we are reducing the marketing expenses and the marketing staffs, and moving people into workout teams and trying to ready to improve the workout and recouping a maximum of our loss. We have some – well, we – the environment – we have some results, but the environment is adverse, so it's difficult to say how far it's going to go. I mean, that clearly it may go further up somewhat.

At BancWest, well, we're really – we were not expecting such high levels and it's in spite of the fact that BancWest is overperforming its yields when you look at the other banks in the U.S., or the Western U.S., even the peers – it works, it even works. So we – BancWest is – we are not happy with this evolution, but we have to admit that most of the, I would say, of the reason is coming from the environment. And also again, we are trying to improve as much as we can and we do everything we can. The evolution, we depend – on those cases, I would say, it will depend on the – I think on the evolution of the economic environment. I mean, if the recession is climbing down in the U.S., if we have only a recession which is short and – relatively short and mild in Europe, it is going to be better BancWest and Personal Finance. If to contrary the recession is deepening further in the U.S. and in Europe, it may cost even more.

So in the emerging markets we – well, it's a very well known question of Ukraine. Well, again, we are really doing everything we can. We are, again, moving people from the commercial side to the workout side, the same thing. We are strengthening the – well, we are not even lending anymore in Ukraine. I mean, it's the extreme case. But the depression is strong in Ukraine. And in the financing businesses, we have – in the other cases, I would say, PF, BancWest and even in Ukraine, as it's about retail, there is a kind of statistical – a formation movement, which can be somewhat – there is a kind of trend and – well, so you – in CIB it's even more difficult to anticipate, because it's about the corporate and you can have a bad quarter, like the first quarter, with a lot of becoming doubtful and creating a significant cost of risk – very significant cost of risk, all of a sudden I would say. Because while it started to deteriorate in the fourth quarter of 2008, but it's much more there. But it may change the following quarter, because it's a – there is no statistical pattern, if you want, in CIB due to the kind of business they are conducting.

So it's – I really can't give you any outlook, any precise outlook for cost of risk. I'm sorry for that. I would like to – I would love to have a precise view. We just do our best to limit the cost of risk, but we are in the midst of a worldwide recession. So, I mean, we – it's a difficult time for banks. So the only thing which is – I would say, which is bringing the kind of support for us is that our – both our domestic markets, France and Italy, are resisting well and probably are suffering less than other countries in Europe.

Now the balance sheet, well, the risk-weighted assets, we are not – our aim is not to go further, I would say. We wanted to go in the region of 500 billion and we had said that we wanted to reduce by 20 billion over the course of the year. So we are there already. So we are going to be very strict in lending and very – I would say, very disciplined and very selective. But our aim is not to go below 500, not at all. So we think that we have also to work and to support some of our clients and to take advantage of the good margin level at the moment. So we have to be both very disciplined, but we want to remain active in the business.

And in terms of Tier 1 target, I mean, we are – our target is clearly expressed in Tier 1 – not in Tier – Tier 1 or core Tier 1 or whatever, due to the fact that it's the way our regulator is reasoning in Tier 1. We have – the non-equity Tier 1 is also real buffer to – as it's – I mean, it's a perpetual reserve and loss absorbing reserves and all the characteristics of the hybrid Tier 1 we have issued are meeting the requirements of our regulators. So our – and to target is given in – is expressed – is given in terms of Tier 1. So the target we have, as you know, is to remain above 7.5%. We have said that given the uncertainties of the time, we wanted to have a buffer, we wanted to be clearly above the target and we think that at the current level, 8.8%, well, is really very significant. So this is what we can say. Now in terms of – I think what – I'm answering your question?
That's fine. Yeah. Thank you very much, yeah.
Welcome.
Thank you. We'll move now to Kinner Lakhani with RBS. Please go ahead.

Yes, hi, good afternoon. Three questions. Firstly, I wonder if you could revisit the yield curve argument on the fixed income strength. I know you talked about the reduced cost of inventory as short-term rates go down. But I wonder if you could address the issue more in terms of the steeping of the yield curve and to what extent and how it plays in your favor.

Second point, the second question may be slightly more strategic on the structured equity derivatives model. Historically, you've explained to us that risk transfer was key part of this model, and clearly it became more difficult to transfer risk. How do you see that developing over the coming years, and therefore your ability to generate earnings on the structured equity derivatives business? And finally, as we go into completion of Fortis, what kind of earnings and profitability should we start to think about compared to the guidance you gave us last October actually?

Okay. Well, on Fortis – to start with Fortis, I don't want to elaborate because we have to put in place now the working groups, which are going to fine-tune the industrial plan. And so I think any kind of new figures or whatever we could give would probably be outdated relatively rapidly and wouldn't be based on the detailed industry plan. So I think we have to wait a little bit before coming back with a more precise figures and clear commitments on the Fortis integration.

On your second question about the structured product in equity derivatives, we – I mean, we – yes, it's true that in the past we were driving probably a very significant part of our equity derivative revenues from selling these core products, structured products for clients, and hedging them and then trying to keep the margin which was embedded in them. And it's true that these source of revenues at the moment is very low on that due to two things. In fact, first, a lower client demand for such products, and due to reluctance on our side to – this is a surprise – because we realized – during the fourth quarter, realized that risk we thought were hedged, in fact, in dislocated markets, were not hedged anymore all of a sudden and we were last with risks which were extremely difficult to manage. So we have decided to reduce that kind of difficult to manage risks and to stay away from that kind of activity.

Now at the same time, what is true for fixed income is also true for equity derivatives. The margins are widening on simple vanilla products, flow product. The margins are widening and so – I mean, you can make a living with flow product. So the need for such structured product is also lower than it used to be when the flow products were commoditized and it was extremely difficult to make significant amounts of money with only vanilla product. So I think that the market is difficult to compare where the market is going to be, with what it used to be, because really we are in the new market, in a new pattern. And so we had to adapt to that new pattern of the market and this is what we have done at the end of fourth quarter and in the first quarter of 2009. And we think that we are now ready to take the best of the new pattern of the market.

Now the yield curve argument, I think it's about – it was relatively easy in the first quarter of this year, the story on the short end of the curve was clear. I mean, the central banks their rates, their key rates and all the yield curve was moving down on the short end. And clearly when you have that kind of visibility and when the cost of carry – the carrying cost of your inventories is lowering that way, it helps the business, the trading business.
Thank you very much.
Welcome.
Thank you. We will move to our next question from Brice Vandamme with Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.
Hi. I think most of my questions have already been answered. But perhaps two things. Could you --
Don't feel obliged.
Sorry?
Don't feel obliged.

No, I will find something that . First, on the CIB side, we used to have in the past a breakdown of your revenue by client activity and trading and other activities. Could you perhaps update us on that? Another thing, which is, I think I looked at your retail activity, especially in France and in Italy. We can see that the outstanding loans you are managing are starting to go down? Could you perhaps explain us what's going on in this activity? Is this because of tightening of your lending conditions or decrease of the demand?

And last question, just a few minutes ago actually the EU Parliament just voted a new rule on banks' capital, especially on the 5% that you have to keep on balance sheet on all LBU you issue, but just under the cap of inter-bank lending activity. Do you think it will have an impact on your activity on the sector overall?

I'll try to take your questions one after the other, and maybe add some more details on what you asked me. On the CIB side, we – yes, this – I would say that in the first quarter we had both – I would say, we had both record level of clients' contribution. We have not – well, we have not – yes, you're right. We have not provided this figure this time. But the clients' contribution was at record level, the highest ever. And at the same time, the addition to the clients' contribution, which is brought by the trading and the hedging of the positions which have taken due to the clients' business, was also very good. In order to get such a result, you can imagine that you have to be good on both sectors. Now your second question about Italy and France, could you repeat your question because I have not completely understood what you --
Yeah. No, the question is just that, having a look at the outstanding amount of loans, we can see that it's starting to go down.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. There is a crisis, there is a crisis. I mean, there is less demand for loans.
Yeah, my question was, is it demand driven or is it also tightening of your lending criteria?

Well, it's mostly – really, it's demand driven. In our domestic markets, we have not really tightened our criteria. We have always been very strict in terms of risk selection and we have not tightened further in the recent months. But the demand for loans is slowing down a lot due to the crisis clearly. So this is the explanation, there is no doubt. For example, in – just to give an example, in the mortgages, for example, there is much less demand for buy to let investors. That kind of activity in the real estate market has dropped to very low level. And so now there are now new incentives in France, which have been put in place by the government, they are really to revitalize this buy to let market, and maybe we're going to see some improvement in the rest of the year. But that's clearly demand driven.

And now about the banks capital, we have always – we are not really suffering that much from that at the moment, because as far as we are concerned we have always – we never practiced the originate and distribute model. We always – for example, in syndications – in syndicated loans when we were – when we are and when we were leading a new facility, we always were keeping part of it, significant part of it, even more than 5%. I mean, very often 10, 15%, as a matter of the policy – I mean, not our policy and a matter also of transparency and loyalty to the clients. And so it's something we have always done. So it is no change for us.
Thank you.
Welcome.
Thank you. Our next question today will come from Derek De Vries with Bank of America – Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Thanks. Good afternoon. I have two questions. The first one relates to the disclosure you give every quarter on the, sort of, sensitive loan portfolios. On page 71 you gave the commercial real estate assets. And you said it didn't really changed at all during the quarter. I mean, you said that's worth 9.2 billion. It doesn't look like you've taken any provisions against this commercial real estate exposure. I was wondering if you could give us some additional data points to get us more comfortable, because certainly if you were to use market prices on that 9.2 billion of exposure, given it looks like it's mostly U.S., California, U.K. and Spain, I think you'd come to a much lower level. So can you give us any comfort there in terms of loan-to-value or covenants, or something to just feel better about that? And also, obviously, no provisions in the quarter, so no deterioration, no internal ratings, downgrades, that sort of stuff.

And then my second question is much more big picture. It looks like you'll finally complete this Fortis acquisition this month, I guess. As you look around the sector, I mean, do you see this as the first of what could be a number of deals, not specifically for you, but just within the banking sector? Do you see people doing more cross-border deals? Or do you think this is a pretty specific one-off case where a bank had run into some problems and you were able to kind of come in and rescue it? That's my second question.

Okay. I'll start with this one. I think that in the current environment, the cross-border deals are going to be very difficult to implement now, because due to the rescue of most banks by – most ailing banks has been rescued by the government. And so I think it's going to be difficult now to organize such kind of cross-border deal.

I guess, I was thinking less of a rescue situation and more of a management team out there saying, you know what, the banking sector has been a long time traded that 1.1 times tangible book, and we used to do deals at two, three times tangible book, let's get on with it.

Well, I think it's difficult. I mean – and if only the delay we have seen since October are showing that that kind of deal is difficult to implement. So I'm not expecting a flurry of such opportunities in the near future. Anyway, as far as we're concerned, we're not going to be involved in such deals for quite a long time, because we have to focus on the profit integration for the next two years. In terms of page 71, you said of the so-called financial stability foreign report of all sensitive information, I'm not finding the 9.2 -
9.2 is just a sum of the 7.2 plus the 1.2 plus the 0.8.

Okay. sorry, sorry, sorry. Yes, I see. Yes, we have – it is true that – this are – those are the sensitive exposures we have in commercial real estate. So we – these are reported such, so I can't they are contrary, and you are right. We – as far as the homebuilders are concerned, we have reduced progressively the commitments to the homebuilders in BancWest from $3 billion in the fourth quarter 2008 to 2.4 billion in first quarter of 2009. It's not – I mean, when you say that there hasn't been any change, in fact there is a slight decline. If you compare with, I think if compare with the same – we are realizing those figures every quarter, so you can compare with the same --
Yeah, I think it was 9.3 billion last quarter, so I said 9.3, 9.2 is probably currency moves I guess. I mean, it's certainly nothing structural. I mean, you still had assets at 98 --
It's the other way around, because the currency is going against us --
But it's not – what I'm talking is structural, not talking of structural change. I mean, it's

No, it's difficult to have any structural change, because when you lent money to – in that sector at the moment, the only thing – you can't do anything else than trying to progressively not renew or reduce your exposure by not – by benefiting from the maturities, the redemptions and not extending new loans or less, because it's something you can't recoup immediately. I mean, it's banking. It's a long-term commitment. So you have lent money for the long run and you can't change that all of a sudden. The quality is not extremely bad so we are – as we said, we have – the most difficult task is on the homebuilders. We have at BancWest 1.7 billion, originally 1.4 is drawn and we try to reduce it gradually and we manage to reduce it gradually, but it's going to be gradual. In CIB it's smaller, it's 400 million.

Now the other – apart from the homebuilders, there is no significant exposure on the property companies. There is a bigger exposure on the, what is called the others. Others meaning it's 5.2 – it's mostly at BancWest, as you can see, €5.2 billion, which is in fact $6.8 billion. And it's lent to – it's relatively well diversified. The underlying goods are properties, are offices for almost 2 billion, retail for 1.7 billion, industrial offices and so different kind of properties and collaterals. We have performed stress test on those loans, the significant one – all the loans, the significant loans, more than $2 million. And we have identified, I would say, the most sensible part of the exposure and we are closely monitoring them. So, yes, the purpose of these assets that we bought in is to provide you with information about the most – but I am sure sensitive exposure. So you have here our exposure in commercial real estate in the countries where the commercial real estate is fragile. So were --
But you don't have any sort of occupancy rates or loan to values or cash flow coverage or anything like that, you can provide us --
I don't have – I don't – we're not disclosing all that, but we are – we tend to be better than the average in the U.S. But it's – it's not necessarily enough to avoid any cost of risk.
And how about, like, internal rating migration? Has the risk-weighted asset allocated to this portfolio gone up even as the assets were declining?

There is not – up to now there is – I would say, there is some – the migration is limited. We have some migration in the – and because of that migration we have some provision on a portfolio basis on those exposures, which I'm not yet doubtful, but are close to watchful – close to the watch list, I mean. So we have built some provision on portfolio basis on those and we are closely monitoring the different cases. And clearly it may – yes, it may feed indeed some of cost of risk at BancWest in the quarters to come.
Okay. Thanks.
Thank you. We'll move now to Jean-François Neuez with Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.
Hello. This is Jean-François from Goldman Sachs.
Hello.

Hello. Two questions on CIB maybe. To start with, in CIB I was just looking at the revenues in the financing division, and they seem to have gone a little bit more lumpy than they used to being up like 30% in the fourth quarter and now down like 13% in the first quarter. I was just trying to understand what were the drivers behind that and whether there was also some yield curve effect on your net Interest income there or things like that, so sort of getting some impression for the underlying development there?

Life insurance.

Yes.

We do have a loss in Ukraine, yeah.

The answer is, yes. I mean, in the context of the integration between Fortis and BNP Paribas there will be some reduction in the balance sheet. I don't expect the size of the balance sheet of the total group to be the addition of the current – the plain addition of the current level of both on both balance sheet. That's for sure. But again it's too early to give figures because again it's going to be part of the industrial plan which we are going to design in the following months – in the next month.

But just let me add that you should not completely mix or – make confusion between de-risking and deleveraging. And typically as repos are concerned, the repo business is a business where the risk is extremely low. Most of the repo is collateralized with government bonds, so the risk is extremely low. And at the same time, you have real de-risking, which I'm not certain with any deleveraging at all. For example, what we have done in the equity derivatives, when you reduce the risk derivatives, you may reduce the exposure you have in derivatives without any impact on the balance sheet figures.

We are done with the reduction of the risk-weighted assets, which ultimately is the best measurement of any risk. So we're there with the derisking, yes. Deleveraging, I mean, is something which we're going to revisit at the occasion of the Fortis integration.

Welcome.

Yes, hi. I've got three questions. The first one relates to the negative unrealized losses in the AFS portfolio of 3.4 billion. Okay. On the first question, you are right. As most of the deterioration in the value of the available for sale equities is due to the decline in the stock exchange prices during the first quarter, the improvements we have seen in those markets is being evaporated or I guess should translate into a reduction in the unrealized losses in the AFS. Well, if it continues until the end of June, which we would hope.

Then on the NPLs, I would say we don't have any target in terms of NPLs. We – of coverage ratio, I mean, certainly not in terms of NPL leader. We adjust each time we have a new files becoming doubtful, we provision it at the level which is adequate. And it just happens that in general when a file become – when there is a new file becoming doubtful, the level of provisioning is not 90% at the beginning at least, because in general very often there is a recovery rate which allows us to have an initial provision level which is more in the region of – depending on the size of course, but it maybe 40, 50 or 60%. And so the fact – the mere fact that we had a lot of additional NPLs and doubtful files in the first quarter has weighed on the coverage ratio.

Second, we had said – yes, we had said while releasing our fourth quarter results in February, we had said that we had provisions, the exposures in Ukraine a little bit ahead of the files becoming effectively doubtful on a portfolio basis due to the deterioration of the country itself. And in the first quarter we had a series of files in Ukraine becoming effectively doubtful, and which were provisioned by cutting, if you want, the collective provision which we have built on the fourth quarter. And it may explain as well part of the reduction in the coverage ratio. Now when you look back in the past, so it has moved between 80 and 90%, so we are not out of the trend over the last few years, I would say. But, yes, it's at 84%. I think we're still relatively high compared with the competition, I would say. Monolines, yes, I checked. You are referring to the Financial Stability Forum reports on slide 74.
Yes.

So the total present value and the total notional were stable over the quarter. In fact, we had some initial changes just due to the increase in the dollars, and so we had no further commutation in the first quarter. Now in terms of CLOs and CDOs, the – yes, we have a slight gross counterparty exposure due to the certain – probably certain – it's not a lot. And it's not – yes, it's really 10% in each case and I think it may be explained just by the some tightening of certain spreads. There are – more generally, the exposure – what has characterized this quarter as far as monolines are concerned, is that the deterioration of the underlying assets according to their market price, I would say, has stopped. So the underlying spread is not significantly different and has even -- as you said, even slightly improved in certain cases compared with the end of December. And the additional cost of the quarter is 100% coming from the deterioration of the monoline spread themselves due to their own evolution. But the underlying exposure, I mean, the market value of the assets which are protected by the monolines has not deteriorated in the quarter. The stress has more or less stabilized in fact from – there have been some movements within the quarter, some deterioration at beginning and some improvement at the end in March. But, overall, we – the spreads went back to the level at the end of December.
Okay. Thank you.
Welcome.

Hi. Good afternoon, everyone. Just a very quick question on advisory in the capital markets. On the capital allocated, I've seen it has increased on a quarterly basis from 3.8 to 5.2 billions. Each beginning of the quarter we allocate capital for the quarter to come based on the capital consumption at the beginning of the quarter. Yeah. Thank you.

It's just a convention, because in fact it's quite logical to – it seems more logical to allocate capital on the basis of the risk-weighted assets at the beginning of the quarter rather than at the end of the quarter. Okay?

Yes, good afternoon. Could you give us just the development regarding the cost of risk in BNL, which is decreasing significantly from the Q4? I think if you look at the – in the past you will see that there is a usual pattern. So the comparison of Q1 and Q4 is not relevant for the cost of risk in retail.
